required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of DCTclock™ as a Cognitive Assessment Aid
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of DCTclock™ as a Cognitive Assessment Aid

brief_summary.textblock: The overall objective of this study is to demonstrate the safety and effectiveness of DCTclock as an adjunctive tool for use by clinicians to evaluate cognitive function in adults aged 55-95.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This study uses a paired design in which each subject undergoes blinded testing by separate testers administering DCTclock and a battery of reference standard tests to determine cognitive state.

primary_outcome.measure: Non-Inferiority of DCTclock Compared to Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
primary_outcome.description: The primary analysis will assess agreement between DCTclock and the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) and compare it to the agreement between the MMSE and MoCA at visit 1.

secondary_outcome.measure: Quadratic Weighted Kappa on Primary Endpoints
secondary_outcome.description: Quadratic weighted Cohen's kappa with 95% CI between DCTclock and MoCA, as well as between MMSE and MoCA.

Positive percent agreement, version A (treating the "Indeterminate" group as "Unimpaired") and version B (removing the "Indeterminate" group from the analysis), and negative percent agreement version A and version B. These were calculated for the DCTclock/MoCA classification table as well as the MMSE/MoCA classification table. 95% CI were also calculated and compared between the two classification tables' calculations.
Linear and rank-linear regression coefficients (slope, intercept) and 95% CI for DCTclock regressed on MoCA as well as for the MMSE regressed on MoCA.
Pearson and Spearman correlation coefficients between DCTclock and MoCA as well as between MMSE and MoCA.

secondary_outcome.measure: Quadratic Weighted Kappa on Secondary Endpoints (Test-Retest Reliability)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 and visit 2, occurring 1-4 weeks apart
secondary_outcome.description: Quadratic weighted Cohen's Kappa statistics were calculated for both DCTclock and MMSE test-retest data (visit 1 vs visit 2).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Agreement on Secondary Endpoints (Test-retest Reliability)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 and visit 2, occurring 1-4 weeks apart
secondary_outcome.description: Positive percent agreement version A (treating the "Indeterminate" group as "Unimpaired") and version B (removing the "Indeterminate" group from the analysis), negative percent agreement version A and version B, indeterminate percent agreement, and unimpaired percent agreement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Regression Coefficients on Secondary Endpoints (Test-retest Reliability)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 and visit 2, occurring 1-4 weeks apart
secondary_outcome.description: Deming, linear, and rank-linear correlation coefficients (intercept, slope) were calculated for visit 1 regressed on visit 2 for both DCTclock and MMSE.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation Coefficients on Secondary Endpoints (Test-retest Reliability)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 and visit 2, occurring 1-4 weeks apart
secondary_outcome.description: Pearson and Spearman correlation coefficients were calculated between visit 1 and visit 2 for DCTclock and MMSE, along with 95% CI.

other_outcome.measure: Construct Validity of DCTclock as Measured by the Comparison of DCTclock Results to the Results of a Battery of Neuropsychological Assessments
other_outcome.description: The goal of this analysis is to assess the construct validity of DCTclock. Specifically, the goal is to compare scores from the administration of DCTclock to the visit 1 administration of a battery of neuropsychological tests, to characterize the psychometric properties of DCTclock, and to compare those properties to the properties of MMSE.

other_outcome.measure: Incidence of Serious Device-related Adverse Events [Safety]
other_outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 and visit 2, occuring 1-4 weeks apart
other_outcome.description: Incidence of serious device-related adverse events.

arm_group.description: Participants received DCTclock, Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), and a battery of other traditional pen and paper neuropsychological assessments.

intervention.description: DCTclock is a quick and non-invasive test that measures cognitive function based on a computerized algorithmic analysis of the entire drawing process and output of a well-established cognitive assessment called The Clock Drawing Test (CDT).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Men and women 55 to 95 years old.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Ineligible for written informed consent.
- Physical impairment of the writing hand.
- Impaired manual dexterity.
- Impaired vision.
- Under the influence of recreational drugs or alcohol at the time of the visit.
- Current or recent participation in a clinical trial that includes the use of a drug or intervention to alter cognitive function.
- Recent cognitive testing.

reference.citation: Lamar M, Ajilore O, Leow A, Charlton R, Cohen J, GadElkarim J, Yang S, Zhang A, Davis R, Penney D, Libon DJ, Kumar A. Cognitive and connectome properties detectable through individual differences in graphomotor organization. Neuropsychologia. 2016 May;85:301-9. doi: 10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2016.03.034. Epub 2016 Mar 30.

Souillard-Mandar W, Davis R, Rudin C, Au R, Libon DJ, Swenson R, Price CC, Lamar M, Penney DL. Learning Classification Models of Cognitive Conditions from Subtle Behaviors in the Digital Clock Drawing Test. Mach Learn. 2016 Mar;102(3):393-441. Epub 2015 Oct 20.

Cohen J, Penney DL, Davis R, Libon DJ, Swenson RA, Ajilore O, Kumar A, Lamar M. Digital Clock Drawing: differentiating "thinking" versus "doing" in younger and older adults with depression. J Int Neuropsychol Soc. 2014 Oct;20(9):920-8. doi: 10.1017/S1355617714000757. Epub 2014 Sep 15.
Davis R, Libon DJ, Au R, Pitman D, Penney DL. THink: Inferring Cognitive Status from Subtle Behaviors. Proc Conf AAAI Artif Intell. 2014 Jul;2014:2898-2905.

patient_data.ipd_description: We do not plan to share IPD

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were enrolled at one site in the US.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 450 participants were enrolled. 14 did not meet screening criteria.

group.title: All Qualified Participants
group.description: Participants received the DCTclock test and a battery of other traditional, pen and paper, neuropsychological assessments.

group.title: All Participants
group.description: All participants enrolled in the study.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Non-Inferiority of DCTclock Compared to Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
outcome.description: The primary analysis will assess agreement between DCTclock and the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) and compare it to the agreement between the MMSE and MoCA at visit 1.
outcome.population: The Evaluable Population includes all qualified participants undergoing cognitive testing with DCTclock, MMSE, and MoCA who completed visit 1.

group.title: Primary Endpoint (Evaluable) Population
group.description: Participants received DCTclock, MMSE, MoCA, and a battery of other traditional pen and paper neuropsychological assessments.

measure.title: Non-Inferiority of DCTclock Compared to Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
measure.description: The primary analysis will assess agreement between DCTclock and the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) and compare it to the agreement between the MMSE and MoCA at visit 1.
measure.population: The Evaluable Population includes all qualified participants undergoing cognitive testing with DCTclock, MMSE, and MoCA who completed visit 1.

analysis.groups_desc: A two-one-sided tests approach was taken, where, prior to analysis, it was determined that a delta (equivalence margin) of 0.20 would be considered a significant difference between the DCTclock/MoCA kappa and the MMSE/MoCA kappa. The reasoning behind this determination can be found in the study's statistical analysis plan.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: In order to show non-inferiority, a lower 90% confidence limit (CL) for the difference in kappa scores would need to be greater than or equal to -0.20. The 90% confidence interval was calculated based on 5000 bootstrapped differences in kappa scores.
analysis.param_type: Lower 90% CL for difference in Kappas
analysis.estimate_desc: 90% CI for Kappa of DCTclock/MoCA - Kappa of MMSE/MoCA (estimated with bootstrap method using 5000 bootstraps).

outcome.title: Quadratic Weighted Kappa on Primary Endpoints
outcome.description: Quadratic weighted Cohen's kappa with 95% CI between DCTclock and MoCA, as well as between MMSE and MoCA.

measure.title: Quadratic Weighted Kappa on Primary Endpoints
measure.description: Quadratic weighted Cohen's kappa with 95% CI between DCTclock and MoCA, as well as between MMSE and MoCA.

outcome.title: Percent Agreement on Primary Endpoints
outcome.description: Positive percent agreement, version A (treating the "Indeterminate" group as "Unimpaired") and version B (removing the "Indeterminate" group from the analysis), and negative percent agreement version A and version B. These were calculated for the DCTclock/MoCA classification table as well as the MMSE/MoCA classification table. 95% CI were also calculated and compared between the two classification tables' calculations.
outcome.population: Version A treats the "Indeterminate" group as "Unimpaired", while version B removes the "Indeterminate" group from the analysis. Thus, the analysis population for version B is smaller than the overall analysis population.

outcome.title: Construct Validity of DCTclock as Measured by the Comparison of DCTclock Results to the Results of a Battery of Neuropsychological Assessments
outcome.description: The goal of this analysis is to assess the construct validity of DCTclock. Specifically, the goal is to compare scores from the administration of DCTclock to the visit 1 administration of a battery of neuropsychological tests, to characterize the psychometric properties of DCTclock, and to compare those properties to the properties of MMSE.
outcome.population: Includes all qualified participants who completed testing at visit 1 and had evaluable data for each test analyzed. Roughly half of the population was administered the full neuropsychological battery. The remainder completed a partial battery (see protocol for details).

group.title: DCTclock
group.description: Participants received DCTclock, MMSE, MoCA, and a battery of other traditional pen and paper neuropsychological assessments.

group.title: MMSE
group.description: Participants received DCTclock, MMSE, MoCA, and a battery of other traditional pen and paper neuropsychological assessments.

measure.title: Construct Validity of DCTclock as Measured by the Comparison of DCTclock Results to the Results of a Battery of Neuropsychological Assessments
measure.description: The goal of this analysis is to assess the construct validity of DCTclock. Specifically, the goal is to compare scores from the administration of DCTclock to the visit 1 administration of a battery of neuropsychological tests, to characterize the psychometric properties of DCTclock, and to compare those properties to the properties of MMSE.
measure.population: Includes all qualified participants who completed testing at visit 1 and had evaluable data for each test analyzed. Roughly half of the population was administered the full neuropsychological battery. The remainder completed a partial battery (see protocol for details).

measurement_list.measurement: Row = Column (correlation of MMSE to MMSE)

outcome.title: Incidence of Serious Device-related Adverse Events [Safety]
outcome.description: Incidence of serious device-related adverse events.
outcome.time_frame: Visit 1 and visit 2, occuring 1-4 weeks apart
outcome.population: All qualified participants who completed at least one DCTclock test.

group.title: All Participants
group.description: Participants received DCTclock, MMSE, MoCA, and a battery of other traditional pen and paper neuropsychological assessments.

measure.title: Incidence of Serious Device-related Adverse Events [Safety]
measure.description: Incidence of serious device-related adverse events.
measure.population: All qualified participants who completed at least one DCTclock test.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data was collected at each study visit. The second (final) study visit occurred one to four weeks after the first visit, therefore, adverse event data was collected for a period of one to four weeks.

group.title: All Participants
group.description: Participants received DCTclock, MMSE, MoCA, and a battery of other traditional, pen and paper neuropsychological assessments.

event.description: Accidental fall resulting in bone fracture.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
